newsitem.title: USA: PacifiCare warns of shortfall, stock tumbles.
newsitem.headline: PacifiCare warns of shortfall, stock tumbles.

text.p: PacifiCare Health Systems Inc. warned Friday that its second-quarter profits would be sharply below expectations, sending the managed health care company's stock tumbling for the second time in a week.

In a statement, the company, based in Cypress Calif., said earnings are likely to fall to between 30 cents and 45 cents a share in the quarter, well below the year ago's operating profit of $1.15 a share and below Wall Street's estimates.
PacifiCare also said it expected to report a substantial drop in earnings for the fiscal year ended in December.
The warning triggered a sell-off in its Class A and Class B stock, which both tumbled $4.94 to $60.94 after earlier falling as low as $55.50 on Nasdaq.

The Class B stock tumbled more than 20 percent earlier this week after company warned of a substantial earnings shortfall in the second quarter. However, Friday's specifics were worse than many analysts had expected.

Prior to the company's warning earlier this week, analysts expected PacifiCare to post second-quarter profits of about $1.16 a share. After the statement, analysts cut their estimates by 10 cents to 20 cents a share.
The company attributed the shortfall to substantially higher health care costs in a number of markets, mainly those acquired in the $2.2 billion purchase of FHP International Co.
Weakness in PacifiCare operations in California and Oregon and one-time expenses for reserve increases and other adjustments were also cited.

PacifiCare said the FHP California operations it acquired in February were performing below expectations, due mainly to a decline in commercial prices in 1996, and are responsible for about 25 percent of the total earnings shortfall expected.
The company also said its own operations in California are being hurt by higher-than-expected prescription drug costs and higher health care costs in its Medicare programme.
PacifiCare also forecast a significantly lower membership growth rate this year in its commercial and Medicare product lines, and said medical loss ratios are expected to increase this year.

"We are obviously disappointed by the performance of a number of these newly acquired assets," President Alan Hoops said in a statement. He added that the integration of FHP operations is proceeding on schedule and according to plan.
